title: Expedia ‘cashing in on cruelty to thousands of dolphins in captivity’
text:
A dolphin is ridden as a surfboard at Zoomarine in Portugal (Picture: World Animal Protection)

An animal rights group is putting pressure on Expedia to follow other tour operators and cut ties with zoos and aquatic parks that keep animals for our entertainment.

World Animal Protection says that the Expedia Group, one of the world’s largest travel companies, should also stop selling tickets to attractions where people are given the opportunity to swim with dolphins.

They found that more than 3,000 dolphins are currently in captivity for human entertainment.

They say that animal lovers are fooled into thinking family-fun shows are aiding conservation but experts say the reality is mammals are experiencing ‘extreme stress and suffering’.

In reality, they are held in ‘tiny, barren, concrete tanks’, and can only swim a few metres a day compared to the 80 miles they would swim in the wild.

Number of animals in captivity Dolphins: 3,029

Orcas: 59

Belugas: 366

Pilot whales: 13

Other cetaceans: 136

The number of captive dolphins kept in tourism facilities by country in 2019 (Picture: World Animal Protection)

WAP’s Nick Stewart also claims that they are exposed to chemicals and are drugged to help them deal with captivity.

Mr Stewart said: ‘By selling tickets to demeaning shows that exploit animals, they are profiting from the suffering.

‘That’s why we are calling on Expedia Group and the remaining travel companies that are still lagging behind to end the sale of tickets to dolphin shows so that we can end their suffering once and for all.’

Expedia said they worked with five animal rights protection groups and had removed some ‘wildlife interactions’ from their websites.

However, WAP wants them to join TripAdvisor, Virgin Holidays, British Airways Holidays and Booking.com which have all cut ties with zoos and dolphinariums.

People doing handstands at Dolphin Bay, Thailand (Picture: World Animal Protection)

In a statement, Expedia said: ‘As the world’s travel platform, we play an integral role in educating travellers about wildlife tourism so they can make informed decisions on how they travel and interact with the animals on our planet.

‘Therefore we have taken steps to remove certain wildlife interactions from our sites not only in reaction to questionable and unsafe practices but in reaction to feedback from our travellers.’

Mr Stewart said: ‘Dolphin entertainment is animal cruelty masquerading as wholesome family fun.

‘Whether bred in captivity or captured from the wild by being torn from their mother’s side, these sociable, intelligent animals are imprisoned for life and reduced to begging clowns performing circus tricks in exchange for food.

In the wild, a dolphin can swim up to 80 miles a day (Picture: SWNS)

‘For a wild animal like the dolphin, a life spent in a concrete box is not a life. It is a life sentence and we need to make this the last generation of dolphins in captivity.’

WAP carried out a survey that found less than 10% of establishments where dolphins were held actually had any substantial form of conservation effort.

In a new report entitled Behind the Smile, they claim that less than 1% of their profits actually went into helping the species and dolphins were merely used as props.

They also found that only six captive-bred dolphins have ever been released into the wild.
